t: Proverbs 18
Contrast the Upright and the Wicked
He*pn who separates himself seeks his*i own*i desire, He*ln quarrels against all sound wisdom.
A*ln fool does not delight in understanding, But*ln only in revealing his own mind.
When*ln a wicked man comes, contempt also comes, And*ln with dishonor comes*i scorn.
The*ln words of a man’s mouth are deep waters; The*ln fountain of wisdom is a bubbling brook.
To*ln show partiality to the wicked is not good, Nor*iln to thrust aside the righteous in judgment.
A*ln fool’s lips bring strife, And*ln his mouth calls for blows.
A*ln fool’s mouth is his ruin, And*ln his lips are the snare of his soul.
The*ln words of a whisperer are like dainty morsels, And*ln they go down into the innermost parts of the body.
He*ln also who is slack in his work Is*ln brother to him who destroys.
The*ln name of the Lord*s is a strong tower; The*ln righteous runs into it and is safe.
A*ln rich man’s wealth is his strong city, And*ln like a high wall in his own imagination.
Before*ln destruction the heart of man is haughty, But*ln humility goes*i before honor.
He*ln who gives an answer before he hears, It*ln is folly and shame to him.
The*ln spirit of a man can endure his sickness, But*ln as*i for*i a broken spirit who can bear it?
The*ln mind of the prudent acquires knowledge, And*ln the ear of the wise seeks knowledge.
A*ln man’s gift makes room for him And*ln brings him before great men.
The*ln first to plead his case seems*i right, Until*iln another comes and examines him.
The*ln cast*i lot puts an end to strife And*ln decides between the mighty ones.
A*ln brother offended is*i harder*i to*i be*i won*i than a strong city, And*ln contentions are like the bars of a citadel.
With*ln the fruit of a man’s mouth his stomach will be satisfied; He*ln will be satisfied with*i the product of his lips.
Death*ln and life are in the power of the tongue, And*ln those who love it will eat its fruit.
He*ln who finds a wife finds a good thing And*ln obtains favor from the Lord.*s
The*ln poor man utters supplications, But*ln the rich man answers roughly.
A*ln man of too*i many*i friends comes*i to ruin, But*ln there is a friend who sticks closer than a brother.
